Bob takes the "bottom up" approach of looking at the specific problem he's attacking, going through the motions of solving it, and through that, he might stumble into some generality that he can later come back to. Alice on the other hand starts from the top. She notices that if she manipulates and connects the abstract pieces of information to finally arrive that the simplest form of the problem, which she then solves.

One of my teachers had a nice saying about it: "Always solve the problem top down, except the first time", echoing the conclusion hit here. Top down problem solving is fast and awesome, but it's really difficult (if not impossible) to solve real problems like that. It often while working through the bottom up tedium that we realize what top down abstractions we can manipulate.

The cosine of the angle between two unit vectors is just their dot product. The dot product with the unit z-vector is just the z-component. So you don't have to go to the lengths of determining the distribution density of theta. All you need is the z-component of the normal vector. Luckily, for evenly distributed unit vectors in 3D, the x, y and z components are all evenly distributed between -1 and 1, so cos(theta) is evenly distributed between -1 and 1 and the absolute is evenly distributed between 0 and 1. Therefore its expected value is 1/2. That's how I tackled that particular part of the problem. No need for fancy calculus here.

I'm definitely more of a Bob thinker here. I conceptualized the problem the Alice way in the beginning, but I wasn't convinced by the idea that you could just look at the faces independently. So I approached the problem by coloring the cube's faces in 3 colors (red, green, blue) such that opposite sides have the same color. Now the whole shadow will always be made up of the shadows of exactly one face of each color. Then you can constrict the problem such that only the upper three faces are considered without losing generality (ignoring edge cases). So the z-components of each normal vector are always positive. Let z1 be the z-component of the red face's normal vector. We know that z1 is evenly distributed between 0 and 1. There is a range of 90° for the cube's rotation around red's normal vector such that the green and blue faces remain on top. So we can calculate the z-components of the remaining normal vectors as
z2 = sqrt(1 - z1^2) * cos(a) and z3 = sqrt(1 - z1^2) * sin(a)
for some angle a that is evenly distributed between 0 and pi/2. Calculating the expected value of z1 + z2 + z3 (which is the expected shadow area) involves a double integral that looks quite scary at first, but is actually pretty simple and allows you the satisfaction of multiplying pi/4 with 4/pi. I was surprised when the result turned out to be 3/2, but after watching this video I understand why it works that way. (But I wouldn't have understood the Alice method without my work on the Bob way.)

okay, I worked the same answer out in a way that wasn't either of these approaches which was interesting to me. Felt very good when the correct formula was revealed and I was right considering a lot of what you were talking about was different from what I did.

If you take a single face of the cube and figure out maximum and minimum surface area (SA) that it can have as a projection you end up with 0 at the minimum and SA at the maximum. We don't need to consider any orientation of the square between these 2 values since we know the distribution of those values is even. If you add 0 and SA together you just get SA and you divide by 2 to get the average. That gets us SA/2 as the formula for any arbitrarily face of the cube.

To figure out how the actual faces relate to the full cube you have to consider what it would mean to have a shadow. The light in this example doesn't come from a point, it comes from a plane. The light is the normal of a "light plane" so to speak and if the normal of a face on the cube will intersect with the light plane then it is receiving light and will cast a shadow. Additionally for any given face on a cube there exists another face where the sum of these 2 faces' normals is zero. This means that for any face that we can say is "in the light" we know for sure there is a corresponding face "in the shadows" and any face in the shadows is one where we can ignore it's area when figuring the total projected area of the cube. With all this in mind the maximum number of faces that can receive light at any time is 3. If 4 faces were receiving light then 4 would have to be in shadow and that's more faces than a cube actually has, values less than 3 are perfectly fine so long as the at least one face is receiving light. If no faces are receiving light then you need to turn the light back on :Y
To put all that in a different way: you only need information about 3 of the faces on the cube to figure out the area of the shadow. In the case of a face where the normal is perpendicular to the light plane's normal you would get a projected area of zero but since the average area we figured out earlier goes from 0 to SA these faces with a projected area of zero are perfectly valid faces to use for determining the projected area.

Since we know how to compute the surface area for an arbitrary face: SA/2, we can easily figure out a formula where any given projection is made up of 3 of these arbitrary faces: 3 * (SA/2) which works out to 3/2 * SA.

So that's how I got 3/2 * SA, which is different from either approach shown here. I could have also figured out the largest and smallest possible projections for the cube and averaged those the same way I did for the square, but that would have required figuring the cross section of the cube and I didn't want to do that let alone try to explain it without any pictures.

I paused the video at some point and tried to come up with my own solution. And I did, but I used a different probability distribution so I ended up with a different result. For those who are interested (and maybe you could check if I'm right 😅):

I paused at the point at which Alice discovered her first 2 key insights (the double shadow and the exploitation of the linearity (=you can average each face on it's own before adding them up)).
So we had the formula S(R_n(Cube))=1/2 * sum(j=1, 6, S(R_n(F_j))
And as said in the video, we can say, that the average shadow of the cube is the sum of the averages of the individual faces divided by 2 (because of the double shadow). The average area of the faces is the same for each face (because none of the faces are special in one or the other way, it's symmetric). Therefore the average shadow of the cube is 6 times the average area of a single face divided by 2. We can cancel the 2 and get that the average shadow area of the cube is 3 times the average area of a single face.
Now we can look at the average area of a single face. The area is completely determined by the angle θ of the normal vector. Now my probability distribution is a uniform distribution of the angle θ from 0 to π/2 (to π wouldn't make any difference, the factor of 2 would cancel later on).
Then we can take the average of cos(x) from 0 to π/2. This is given by the integral of cos(x) dx from 0 to π/2 all over the length we integrate over, in this case π/2-0=π/2.
The integral of cos(x) dx is of course sin(x)|(π/2, 0)= sin(π/2)-sin(0)=1.
Therefore the average area is 1/(π/2)=2/π.
Now multiply that with 3 and you get 6/π as the average area of the shadow of the cube.

By far the best part of this video, for me, was the introspective part about which is "better", and what that means in relation to YouTube content.

I feel like there's a significant incentivization on a platform like YouTube toward the Alice approach. Because, like you said, the method of explaining it is relatively independent of the viewer's background, that means the closer you get to Alice's explanation, the closer you get to maximizing your possible viewership, and thus monetization.

I often wish channels would be less afraid to show the math... but you really crystallized why they don't, here. In order to dive into the math, i.e. Bob's approach, you have to accept one of two premises: Either you're going to accept that your video is not for all viewers, i.e. your ratio of actual viewers to potential viewers is strictly less than 1... or you have to make your individual channel as close to a complete education on the subject as possible. This is...

Hmm, actually, I was about to say that this is too much work for a single YouTuber... but actually, on further thought, I don't think that's the problem. There are YouTubers who come pretty close to that ideal, at least to a point, with things like Crash Course, or Sean Carroll's Big Ideas series. Rather, the proportion of potential viewers who will be interested in that level of detail is also strictly less than 1.

My intuition is that the Bob method, i.e. the complete education approach, loses viewer ratio far more dramatically the more detailed you go. At the ultimate level of putting together the equivalent of a college education in a subject (such as MIT's OpenCourseWare), you would not only lose the beginners who aren't inherently extremely interested in the subject; you would also lose most experts as well. Even if you did such a thing, you would end up in active, direct competition for the attention of those enthusiastic beginners with actual educational institutions. Granted, you'd be doing it for free, but... well... you'd be doing it for not that much ad revenue compared to what a major university can pull in for the same effort.

So... there would seem to be some kind of function that defines the optimal level of detail to capture as large a percentage of the potentially interested audience as possible. The global maximum of that function would presumably be influenced by the general education level of YouTube Viewers as a population, or at least of the subset of them who are at all interested in math videos. But within those would be local maxima determined by the competition from other YouTubers.

You are implicitly assuming continuity of the function mapping surfaces (under some metric where larger polyhedral approximations of a sphere are arbitrarily close to a sphere) to average shadow, which, although may be true depending on your choice of metric, was hand-wavy and unconvincing to my ears. I'm sure you've seen the false argument that the unit circle has radius 8 using a sequence of step functions approaching the circle that all have length 8, so you know how misleading and dangerous that kind of argument can be.

A better way to show what you want would be to construct a sequence of lower bounds with the desired result as a supremum, and another sequence of upper bounds with the desired result as an infinum; in this case, this would look like a sequence of polyhedrals with vertices on the sphere and one of polyhedrals with faces tangent to the sphere. It shouldn't be too hard to justify an argument given this idea (and you wouldn't have to worry about choosing a metric and proving its properties).

I found quite an appealing physics-oriented proof using Gauss law for EM fields. Hope you enjoy :)


1 - Imagine the cube standing in the Euclidean 3D space, and imagine a physical sphere of radius R (where R >> 1) whose center coincides with the center of the cube. Further assume that the sphere carries an overall electrical charge of 1C, uniformly distributed over the surface of the sphere.

2 - Now, look at some differential area da on the sphere. It generates an electrical flux dF through the surface of the cube. Obviously, since the cube lies inside the sphere, it contains no charge and dF=0. But we can further decompose:

dF = dF_in + dF_out = 0

When dF_in is the positive contribution to the flux (entering the cube), and dF_out stands for the negative contribution to the flux (exiting from the cube).

3 - There is another symmetry to account for: for each differential area da around some point x on the sphere, we can associate the differential area da' around the antipodal point -x also lying on the sphere. Denote by dF and dF' the corresponding contributions to the flux. From the problem's symmetry we get:

dF_in = dF'_in and dF_out = dF'_out

4 - If we move a differential charge dQ from the sphere to the inside of the cube, its contribution to the flux jumps from dF_in + dF_out = 0 to -dF_in + dF_out = -2 * dF_in

5 - Now, using (3) and (4 ) and Integrating the flux over the whole sphere and moving the overall charge inside the cube, we get the following relationship between the total flux after the shift, and the total incoming flux before the shift:

|F_shifted| = 4 * |F_in|

Now we can let the magic happen:

6 - From Gauss Law, we get:

|F_shifted| = 1

7 - ...But taking R to infinity, and using the definition of the flux, it's quite obvious that |F_in| (up to some irrelevant physical constant) is exactly the averaged normalized shadow area of the cube!!!

Indeed you can think of each differential dF_in generated by a charge at some point x on the sphere as the relative contribution to the averaged shadow associated with the angular position of x relative to the cube's center.

8 - Therefore,

E(S(shadow)) / S(cube) = |F_in| = 1/4 * |F_shifted| = 1/4

as expected.

Besides requiring no integration and giving a good intuition for the final 1/4 factor, this proof technique also generalizes to any orientable 2D surface (say a n-holes torus) since Gauss Law doesn't care about the the fundamental group of the enclosed surface. Therefore, 1-connectedness is easily shown to be un unneeded assumption.

ok, I just got to minute 2:41 and I have thought of a way of doing it:

Step by step and explanation of why:

1) take the cube and make it a square by choosing a face of it, then calculate the area

2) on the same face (of the cube) find the hypothenuse, and make it the diameter of a circle, then calculate the area.

the reason why we do this is: since we are being asked the average of the area of the cube ON ANY position, then by doing this we are finding the maximum area the cube's shadow can occupy when the face of it, its perpendicular to the floor and thus we know it cant be larger than that (on that specific orientation)

3) on the before found hypothenuse make it the base of a triangle with the height of the cube being the other side then repeat the process of step 2 AND make this new-found hypothenuse the diameter of a circle and find its area.

the reason why we do this: when a cube is tilted at 45 degrees (using the floor as reference) the shadow becomes the largest it can possibly be on ANY position (since it is the line that goes from the top corner of a cube to the bottom corner diagonally to the opposite side) and thus by making this hypothenuse the diameter of a circle and calculating the area we are calculating the maximum area the cube's shadow can occupy (on any scenario).

4) add the area of the two circles together (to combine the maximum area of the largest and smallest area the cube can occupy while being on a state of "superposition", meaning basically you just spin it until it becomes a full on circle) then also add the area of a normal face of the cube then divide by three to get the average.

NOTE: It might not be necessary to add the area of a face of the cube I just did it to find the minimal area the cube can occupy while not being on a state of "superposition"

I think that the argument — the ratio is constant, circa 33:40 in the video — to show that the relationship between average shadow and surface area holds in the limit of infinitesimally small faces, is flawed. That the ratio is constant in the discrete case is not sufficient to prove that it takes the same value in the continous limit, though I am convinced that in this particular case, this is true.

The simplest counter-example I can think of, is considering the square [0,1]x[0,1] in the plane, and all the paths that go from the point (0,0) to the point (1,1) making alternating steps along positive x and positive y (but never diagonally along positive x and y). It is clear that any such path with a finite number of steps is of constant length 2 (1 along x, and 1 along y), yet in the limit of infinitesimally small steps, the length of the corresponding path is between square root of 2 (the diagonal of the square) and 2 (one of the paths along the sides).

I'm reminded of two further examples of the same slick idea.

1. The triangle inequality: It's easy to see that for any real numbers x,y, we have |x|+|y| ≥ |x+y| (there are two cases, if they have the same sign or they have opposite signs). Now if I have a vector v in the plane, and P is the projection to a line in a random direction, then the average length of Pv must be c|v| for some proportionality constant c. On the other hand, if I have two vectors v,w in the plane, we have |Pv|+|Pw| ≥ |Pv+Pw| = |P(v+w)| for all projections P (by the real number case). Hence taking expected values on both sides, we get c|v|+c|w| ≥ c|v+w|, so |v|+|w| ≥ |v+w|, which is exactly the triangle inequality for vectors.

2. Buffon's needle problem: This is basically the same problem as in this video, but one dimension lower. "Suppose there are infinitely many parallel lines on the floor, equally spaced at distance 1 apart. Toss a straight needle of length 1 onto the floor; what is the probability that it lands on a line?"
- This probability is the same as the expected number of times that the needle crosses a line.
- Now replace the shape of the needle with any polygonal path; note that the expected number above is just proportional to the length of the needle, independent of its shape.
- To find the proportionality constant, consider a needle in the shape of a circle with diameter 1 (which has circumference pi). Then it (almost) always crosses the lines in exactly two points. Hence the proportionality constant is 2/pi. This is also the desired probability in the original problem (since the original needle has length 1).
This solution is sometimes jokingly referred to as "Buffon's noodle".

Alice specifies the probability measure when she assumes that the face-to-shadow ratio doesn't depend on the initial orientation of the face (without this assumption, the rest of the argument falls apart). Since an initial orientation corresponds to some element of SO(3) (say A), we essentially end up multiplying everything in our probability space by A on the right (since we first choose the initial orientation, then do the rotation).

Thus, the probability measure must be invariant under right multiplication - i.e. it is a right Haar measure. By Haar's theorem, this measure exists and is unique (if we assume some basic regularity), so Alice has specified the distribution. Of course, this distribution happens to be the same as the one Bob described explicitly (pick a normal vector randomly from the surface of a sphere, then rotate the cube by a random amount about the normal - uniformly both times).

Interestingly, this can be seen as another example of the difference between Alice and Bob's approach. Bob provides a concrete and specific definition of the probability measure; Alice assumes a basic property (invariance under right multiplication) and appeals to an abstraction (Haar's theorem) to do the heavy lifting. She never describes the measure, nor does she have to. And this happens a lot in math - we talk about the existence of an object satisfying a particular property, without ever explicitly constructing it.

You can never get a "real answer" that is absolute anyways, because there are infinite possible rotation positions on 2 valid rotations and one invalid rotation.

Rotating on "Y" (horizontal), there is no change, across each possible rotation of (Z,X)... So, what is "average" within the span of infinity? You can plot an average of predefined "stops", for each axis, but that isn't the average. The more stops you make, the more the average changes. You are adding more "non-changing Y rotations" to more "changing (Z,X) rotations". The "average" would only get more precise, within a span of infinite decimal representations, but never become "resolved", in "reality" as an "absolute" of anything. {Z,X would only have 2/3 impact on the average, because 1/3 of the rotations have zero change to the area of the shadow, but that IS part of the average too.}

A one-minute average solution for any convex solid. (aka the engineer's route)

Call the projected area of the convex solid A(cs). The answer we are looking for is thus Average(A(cs))

Construct the inscribed sphere in your convex solid, and formulate an expression for the surface area of its projection (A(isphere)), this should be fairly easy to do. A(cs) is obviously always greater than A(isphere).
Thus: A(isphere) < A(cs)
(In the case of a cube, A(isphere) works out to be 1/4(pi))

Now construct the sphere in which the solid sits (I'm certain this has a name in English, but I don't know it), and formulate an expression for the surface area of its projection (A(esphere)). A(cs) is obviously always smaller than A(esphere).
Thus: A(isphere) < A(cs) < A(esphere)
(In the case of a cube, A(esphere) works out to be 3/4(pi))

The average between A(isphere) and A(esphere) should be a suitable estimation for most practical uses for A(cs).
(In the case of a cube, A(cs) approximates pi/2)

I realize that there are far more accurate solutions, but I figured this one was the best for engineers in a hurry.

33:26 this doesn't work for the same reason that a 2-dimensional "staircase" of infinitely small steps has the same total step length as a staircase with only one step, i.e. moving across and then up and only changing direction once.
A sphere is a "shorter path", or, smaller surface area, than a convex hull of infinitely small faces- identically analogous to how a "ramp" instead of a "staircase" is shorter by "sqrt(2) - 2" units if the rise/run = 1.
No amount of "shrinking the faces" of the "sphere" (which has a specific name: an icosphere) will ever cause the surface area to "approach" that of a normal sphere as would happen in an integral. The surface area will suddenly equal the true sphere's area /only/ when the faces have 0 area. The function has a binary output and that is either the surface area of an icosphere or the surface area of a sphere.

Am I missing something, or is the argument starting at 15:00 missing something very important? Clearly the double coverage claim doesn't hold for, say, an angled light source or a nearby light source, even for a convex object. Merely the fact that each light ray passes through exactly 2 faces is not sufficient. To take a simpler example, imagine a light source above the interval (0,1) but at an angle so that the shadow covers the interval (0, 2). Each light ray passes through exactly 1 point in the top interval, but the bottom one has twice the length. 1-1 is not sufficient because cardinality and measure are very distinct notions, and the function has to be measure-preserving to conserve area. While I understand that this video already covers a lot of ground and introducing measure would take its own video entirely, I do think it's misleading not to point out the fact that this argument only works for the infinitely distant light source (since the map (x, y, z) -> (x, y, 0) from one horizontal plane to another preserves Lebesgue measure).

With it, I was able to identify a few symmetries - rotating the system around the z axis doesn't affect the area, meaning that it doesn't matter which face we "focus on" when performing a rotation.

I already knew that the projection had an area of s²cos(theta) from general experience and reasoning, and because of the symmetries found earlier, I knew that I only had to consider angles from 0 to π/2 radians. This reminds me of Art of Problem Solving's Richard Rusczyk's excellent article on What is Problem Solving. In it he mentions that there are two ways that people often view mathematics. One is as a collection of separate tricks to use on a series of specific problems. Trick A is for Problem A, Trick B is for Problem B, and so on. In this way school can become a routine of 'learn tricks for a week - use tricks on a test - forget most tricks quickly.' The tricks get forgotten quickly because there are so many of them and also because the students don't see how these 'tricks' are just extensions of a few basic principles.

The other way to see mathematics is to realize that all of these 'tricks' stem from several basic, but fundamental principles and ideas. And mathematics is then an exploration of where you can get from these same guiding ideas. In this way mathematics isn't a disconnected bag of magic tricks, but rather a connected web to be explored. As Rusczyk points out, "the successful mathemati cian possesses fewer tools, but knows how to apply them to a much broader range of problems."

For instance, Alice's approach in this video can be seen in a nutshell as a creative application of linearity of expectation. The mathematical techniques used are all elementary, and someone who's taken a first course in probability/stats might have learnt linearity of expectation though maybe not thought deeply about its possible implications. Further, Alice's approach as a whole isn't just an isolate trick in itself. When I saw her idea, I realized that it was a neat generalization of the same ideas used to solve Buffon's Needle, another famous classic problem.

I think I've figured out what assumption Alice made about the distribution. She treats the faces independently., meaning that given rotation R, she takes each face as starting out flat on the ground and having R applied to it, and weights that by the probability P(R) associated with R. But if you orient the whole object according to R, the faces don't all start flat on the ground -- face i has an initial rotation Rf[i] representing its position in the shape. So the appropriate weight to use for R with face i is actually P(R * Rf[i]). Since Rf[i] can be anything for a general shape, for these two choices of weighting to give the same result we need the probability distribution to be invariant under an arbitrary 3D rotation. I think this is the sort of thing Grant meant when he talked about symmetries in the numberphile video.

I work in research and regularly get asked quite general questions about how much time and money it will take to build something, if it's even possible, or what range of performance could be expected of the final product.

I start with checking what has been done, and what the performance was, then pro rata to the scale requested to "fail fast" and minimize wasting company resource. if the pro rata business case is an order of magnitude or more off working then it's a non-starter.

Some times it isn't a thing that's been done, so I have to make some assumptions from the basic physics principles and present an area of uncertainty the answer could lay within, like one of those areas between discreet points on the surface of a continuous sphere.

Sometimes I conclusively prove that it impossible, but what I report is that if they want to achieve that goal, they will have to be flexible with some of the other requirements.

Throughout the development process it is a certainty that the target will be moved and we'll have to provide estimates for other scenarios. For this reason I tend to solve the specific problem at hand immediately, whilst contemplating the general problem, so that I can modify my singular solution to apply to any scenario when that request is inevitably made. Hopefully I can work fast enough to give them an almost immediate general answer which reduces the waste of my time repeating excessively accurate repetitive calculations.

As an example: chocolate is a wrong material to chose to make a robust teapot from as it will taint the tea with chocolate, is likely to melt at tea steeping temperatures, and thus would not survive multiple repeated uses. So it isn't necessary to calculate how bad the chocolate contamination would be, or how much tea the pot could make before it failed. Knowing it would fail in closer to one use than 100 uses is enough certainty to disregard the concept without doing any math or experimentation. But the logic used informs the factors which future material choices need to consider and what the tacit operational requirements of the product may be beyond those explicitly stated. This immediate feedback without doing the maths for how long it would last enables you to get feedback on if work should continue on the concept, and to start on the "tool" with which to assess and compare future material options with if you're told to continue.

The most fascinating thing for me to have to wrap my head around, is how people will accept familiar but wrong results far more willingly than they would perfect results which aren't anticipated. Even when the accuracy effects future profitability and there are huge advantages of getting it right first time. Often participating in science is sadly as much about social engineering as it is scientific.

I love the discussion on the "tug-of-war" between intuition and calculation. Whenever I approach a generalizable problem, it is true that I often try to step back and try to spot an intuitive pattern before diving deep into the details. It helps to have an initial intuitive impression as a guide before you start. However, intuition, when not built on a strong foundation, could lead to a trap. It is possible that I might have missed a key assumption, or misinterpreted a concept that is central to the problem. I most often detect the error on intuition once I am in the middle of the dirty calculations, which might have had led me to a formula that does not make sense, or to some other false mathematical statement. It is rare that my intuition led me straight to a smooth solution. And if it does, it's almost always the case that I have done similar problems in the past already, such as hidden angle-hunting in a high school geometry problem, or a seemingly complex integral solved using an "obvious" substitution which I might have never thought of when I was first studying calculus.

Thus, relying on intuition indeed requires slick and stylish creativity, but also a great deal of luck and experience. Intuition isn't born; it is made. Through piles and piles of crumpled papers and boxed equations and messy notes. Calculation is the tool you use to build your craft. Intuition is knowing the appropriate tool to use. And you could only know which tool is best if you have used them all extensively.

I'm a sociology student who actually primarily does qualitative work, and this video is fascinating to me. Qualitative methods often employ this method called grounded theory, whereby researchers sift through data to find contradictions to currently established theories. Social sciences rely on the fact that inductive logics require abductive analyses to generate new information. As we update theories using this grounded approach, our theories converge upon universal and general realities, allowing for us to see, describe, and make predictions about society.

It's fascinating because Alice's intuitions genuinely build new math, but Bob's experience allows for him to have to build those intuitions. In qualitative research, Alice's intuition would allow for her to abductively identify a contradiction with theory, refining her puzzling until she revises the contradiction. Alice's intuitions would get taught in undergraduate sociology courses, and become the established theories future researchers contend with.

However, for her to even have to even have that insight, Alice had to previously work like Bob. Building intuitions takes experience, and in sociology it comes from looking closely at the inductive reasoning and abstraction that had caused previous researcher to come to conclusions.


This video is really similar to the problem of middle range theory in sociology, where the earliest sociologists of the previous centuries posited grand philosophical theories of how the world worked. However, those theories were oftentimes descriptive, but too grand, making many errors which contradict with the empirical realities of the changing world.

Now the invention of radical new theory is discouraged in sociology, and middle range theory which revises older theory to grapple with new empirics is favored. Being a philosophical visionary causes someone to get canonized in the field, but it is a disingenuous way to produce new knowledge.

Excellent discussion of different styles of mathematical thinking!  Personally, my approach to this problem is more like Alice's, but starting from the opposite direction. Without going into a 40-minute description, here is a brief summary:  Thinking that the rotations of a cube cast complicated shadows, I began by considering a simpler case: a sphere.  This of course casts a circular shape regardless of rotation, so the average shadow is the only shadow, thereby eliminating the need to consider the rotation at all.  Then, observe that a sphere inscribed inside a cube, or any convex polyhedra, will have a smaller shadow than the cube. Likewise, a sphere circumscribed around the cube will have a larger shadow than the cube.  So these two spheres form lower and upper bounds on the average shadow, and the closer the polyhedra is to a sphere, the closer the shadows of the two spheres will be to the average shadow of the polyhedra. Notice also that rotations of any fixed point on the polyhedra will mark out a sphere between the circumscribed and inscribed spheres, with rotations of the polyhedra essentially filling the space between the two spheres.  Arriving at the same observation of Alice that the average shadow is proportional only to the surface area, we can immediately conclude that the average shadow of a polyhedra is the same size as the shadow of a sphere with the same surface area.

The value of the constant “c” in the way it is defined (the average of the scaling factors of the areas of shadows in various orientations) is in fact dependent on the probability distribution of various orientations. Since the various faces of the cube (or generally any convex polyhedron) have different orientations (but these orientations are fixed with respect to each other) if the distribution is not uniform the value of “c” may in fact be different for different faces of the cube. One can still go from adding row-wise to column-wise in case of arbitrary probability distributions, but one may not conclude that the average area of each face’s shadow is the same constant times the area of that face.

For instance if the probability distribution is biased towards one of the faces of the cube always nearly facing the light source, the average area of the shadow of that face and it’s opposite face will be greater than the average area of the shadow of the other other faces.

Among all possible probability distributions of the orientations, only the uniform probability distribution will ensure that regardless of the shape of the convex object, each face will still have the same factor “c”.

I've been waiting for this video for years ever since the first video on the surface area of a sphere and had honestly thought you had abandoned it. I'll give my best idea for how Alice avoids talking about distributions of orientations but it is somewhat longwinded.

Alice gets around the distribution problem when she uses her original result that for any given rotation, the shadow area of a 2d shape is proportional to the area of that shape. this is wrong because Alice is not in fact starting with a 2d shape in a 2d plane as you show at 10:15. She is instead starting with a 2d shape in 3d space. When you do this you do not get the same result that shadow area is proportional to shape area. For example, if we apply a certain 90-degree rotation to a unit square parallel to the plane we're projecting onto, the shadow area is 0 times the area of the square but if we apply that same rotation to a unit square perpendicular to the plane, we get 1 times the area of the square.

In a roundabout way, Alice is assuming that all orientations are equally likely when she says that the average shadow area across all orientations is a constant times the actual area. This is best illustrated with the above example. The two squares only have the same average shadow area when each rotation R has the same probability as that rotation composed with the rotation S that maps one square onto the other. When this is the case, for every rotation where the shadow area of the perpendicular square is A and the parallel square is B, there is another equally likely rotation where the shadow area of the perpendicular square is B and the Parallel square is A.

When dealing with the six sides of the cube, any distribution with cube-like symmetry will give the same average area for each side but when she starts approximating a sphere with increasingly complex polyhedra the only distribution that gives each patch of area the same average shadow area constant is a uniform distribution.

I wanted to mention Newton as an example of a genius doing insane amounts of math legwork in his original works, but of course you did it yourself (it wouldn't be 3Blue1Brown if you hadn't ;-) ).

The truth of the matter is, genius does not lie in avoiding the tedious calculations, but emerging out of them with (a) the correct results, and (b) a ton of fresh intuition gained. To illustrate, here's a story of how an ordinary mortal, yours truly, once attempted to extract Newton's result that a planet moving under the influence of an inverse square force law traces an ellipse.

I was just out of high-school, about to enter university classes as a freshman in physics (having scored excellently in my entrance exams). At that point, I was familiar with calculus (differentiation, integration, limits, an inkling of how to solve 1st order differential equations by finding anti-derivatives). I knew about the principle of compositing independent motions, e.g. getting a parabolic trajectory for a projectile by adding up a uniform motion with a free fall. So, I thought I could easily do the same for the problem of planetary motion by compositing the inertial (tangential) motion of a planet with its vertical fall towards the center of the Sun.

I soon found myself hopelessly bogged in insurmountable difficulties, as the vertical direction changed from point to point of the trajectory, which did not happen in the simple parabolic trajectory problem. How long a step should my "planet" take tangentially, before gravity pulled it down? And which direction should it be pulled down, the one at the beginning or the one at the end of the step? I soon gave up, utterly confused. Later in my studies, when I encountered a solution using conservation of angular momentum, I was convinced: this was the way to go; Newton would never have taken such a silly and naive approach.

And yet, as I found out later still, Newton did take exactly this "naive" approach - the difference being, he saw it to the end and didn't give up like I did! Instead of wondering how long a step I should be taking, I should have pondered how the solution changes as I take smaller and smaller steps, to the limit of vanishingly small ones. The elegant solution I encountered in textbooks came much later, after the work of Euler and Lagrange and Hamilton.

So, that's my story; make of it what you will.

33:32 There is even more subtlety here: you can't just pick an arbitrary sequence of geometric approximations and get the same surface area every time. See the "Schwarz lantern" for an example of the difficulties of approximating surface area this way. So you have to make some statements at least about the type of polygonal solids you are approximating with and justify why that gives the correct limiting result, and why that result is the same as for the true sphere.

Another classic example of this sort is "approximating" the length of the diagonal of a unit square with a sequence of staircases having progressively finer steps. The length of the staircase curve is always 2 and never changes no matter how many steps you add; it fails to converge to the true length of the diagonal sqrt(2).

A few in random order:
- Youtube/videos: Alice videos are catchier, shorter, easier to follow => "Sells better" online.
- When you teach maths or a science that relies heavily on it, people tend more to be in the Alice Mindset. Learning/building nice theories harmonise better with an elegant mindset. When the same people get out to practical work, they often drift toward a "Worker Mindset", which is Bob's case here. People should aim for a balance between the two, depending on the work they do, and also be conscious of those self-set boundaries, and when they leave them.
- I always teach the "Healthy Laziness Philosophy". Before you jump on grinding out a solution, or solutionise something, have a look and see what are the things that you can generalise and avoid doing the same work multiple times. (This applies to most areas of life, not just maths. e.g. very useful in IT.) It usually takes some experience to guess efficiency turns on and off steps of generalisation, but that's something one can acquire over time.
- Bob's approach can be "safer" but more laborious. Alice's approach is riskier but potentially much faster and prone to less human errors. The problem is that we are talking about literal risks. You typically can't tell in advance whether there is an elegant/generalised solution or not, PLUS whether you can find it in a reasonable amount of time. In an ideal situation you have both Alice and Bob, let them start pursuing their paths, and after a time check in with both and have a discussion on the progresses. Independent presentation and then communication between Alice and Bob is crucial.
- Bob's approach is safe in the sense that it only applies to cubes. You can always use it with cubes, and it's a proven track to get there. Alice's approach has a few potential mines. e.g.: You may not be conscious about some of the assumptions you have made along the way. This is especially true when you dabble with infinites in any way. You tend to remember the base problem and the generalised solution, forgetting even some of the assumptions you have consciously made, and this can draw you into reusing the generalised solution where those assumptions do not apply.
- People are different, and have a different level of agility in different levels of abstraction. Some mindsets are better toward Alice's end of the spectrum, while others on Bob's end. (And this is obviously not a good-bad thing.) Always make sure to apply the appropriate person (mind) in a given area+problem. It will be better for the problem and better for the person. (Again, this is something that leads out of maths.)

I'm not fully convinced of the generalization of convex solids and the sphere that doesn't have planar faces. Intuitively it does make sense, but there's a related "paradox" that gets me in the way of that intuition:

Take a rectangle of sides (a,b). We want to find out what's the length of the diagonal (without using pythagoras).

One way I would go about it is to consider all the paths that go from one corner to the other by doing vertical/horizontal lines:

* Without splitting the path, the distance will be a + b (starting from bottom-left corner - we go up, then right)
* If we split each side once, the distance will be a/2 + b/2 + a/2 + b/2 = a + b (we go half-way up, then half-way right, then to the top and then right)
* If we split each side three, the distance will be a/3 + b/3 + a/3 + b/3 + a/3 + b/3 = a + b (etc.)
And the more times we turn, the closer our path is the diagonal itself.
We could then make the limit to when the number of splits reaches infinity, where intuitively we will have the diagonal:
Lim(s -> inf, s * (a + b) / s) = Lim(s -> inf, a + b) = a + b
Which gives us a wrong answer - By following pythagoras it should be sqrt(a*a + b*b)

Sidenote regarding your argument at 33:30 :

You argue, that one can simply take the limit of the approximations of the sphere and then compare it to the result of the sphere. However I find this argument to be a little flawed (even though it works here). My concern here is that, given that all steps fullfill some property that does not necessarily extend to the limit. A common example for this is Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem, which is needed exactly because the integral of the limit of functions f_n does not necessarily equal the limit of the integral of f_n. Another easier example is that the limit of a series of continuous functions does not need to be itself continuous, e.g. x^n is continuous on [0,1] for all natural n, but the limit (for n going to infinty) is not continous, since it equals 0 everywhere on [0,1) and 1 at x=1. Would be cool if you maybe somehow include this sidenote to this video, since it was a common mistake of mine, when I started studying mathematics at university.
